- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/622336/12 : FAILURE in 2h 56m 56s'}, {'account_id': 32015, 'date': '2020-05-31 23:31:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

I tested this patch against the master branch, as of 30/03/2020. On a fresh install of devstack running on Ubuntu server 18.04.

Here some insights about functionality:
- Tested creating the instance via horizon and defining the "console_passwd" - Ok
- Tested console access via horizon (with and without password) - Ok
- Tested updating the "console_passwd" metadata via horizon - Ok, but the password is only effectively updated in libvirt afeter a new request for a console. This can cause confusion if the user is using an external agent to access the instance.
- Tested the change in the nova-API call to change the password - Ok

Some other things to keep in mind:
- Once the instance is started without a password libvirt won't accept to reconfigure it with password protection. The API call return successful but libvirt ignores it until the instance is shutdoff and restarted.
  The reverse operation is also not possible, starting the instance with password and trying to remove it later doesnt work (until the instance is restarted).
I believe those are libvirt limitations.

In regard with the original Blueprint, there is some inconsistency:
The blueprint states, under "Security impact":
"(...)"note that console password will only be securely kept by libvirtd and won’t be displayed in the result of virsh dumpxml <instance UUID> or definition XMLs managed by libvirt /qemu in local filesystem except. Briefly speaking, no potential security risks will be introduced."
That's partially true: virsh dumpxl do not show the password, but it is written to the libvirt/qemu local filesystem file (i.e /etc/libvirt/quemu/instance-XXXX.xml, and can be read from this file.
I understand that this is not a limitation and is due to the way this patch implements the Blueprint. This can be improved in the future.

I find this patch very useful for my usage case, in which end-users access the instances via external agent (spice protocol via remote-viewer in my case). Today one user can simply kick/steal another user session from an instance just by connecting to it. This patch would solve this issue (once it implements spice support)- I'll try do it on my own but this is my first contact with openstack development.

Last but not least:
- Had only one simple merging conflict (cause of new API version) - easily fixed
- The zuul failure is due to an unused variable - easily fixed'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2020-09-17 06:03:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

>

Thanks Tiago Bitarelli Gomes tested for this patch, I will update and resolve this conflict. Unfortunately, the function of nova in V release has been frozen, this will be done in Wallaby release I can try. The -1 is for the unicode password issue plus some doc and test nits. However, I'm beginning to get nervous about this. My initial understanding of this was that the authentication would be implemented between the user and the proxy. Instead, we're implementing at the QEMU end. As I've noted inline, this means we lose the ability to encrypt the traffic from the proxy to the guest on the host, which seems like a seriously backwards step. I need to think about this more but I'm far from convinced that this is a good idea looking at it now."}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2021-02-18 11:29:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30:

(1 comment)

Looking into this more, it sounds like what we want is to support the 'X509Vnc' subtype for the 'VeNCrypt' security type, as opposed to the 'VNC' security type. These are all well documented in the RFB protocol doc [1]. I would be okay with supporting both for users who don't want to configure TLS for their deployments (crazy people, IMO) or for development purposes, however, the latter should have a big warning noting that it's not really secure and shouldn't be used in production and the former must be in place IMO. Anything less means this feature is either useless or actively harmful, IMO.

Adding melwitt to the review, who might have some more thoughts on the matter (she's worked on this stuff before also)

[1] https://github.com/rfbproto/rfbproto/blob/master/rfbproto.rst#72security-types"}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2021-02-18 23:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30:

> Patch Set 30:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> Looking into this more, it sounds like what we want is to support the 'X509Vnc' subtype for the 'VeNCrypt' security type, as opposed to the 'VNC' security type. These are all well documented in the RFB protocol doc [1]. I would be okay with supporting both for users who don't want to configure TLS for their deployments (crazy people, IMO) or for development purposes, however, the latter should have a big warning noting that it's not really secure and shouldn't be used in production and the former must be in place IMO. Anything less means this feature is either useless or actively harmful, IMO.
> 
> Adding melwitt to the review, who might have some more thoughts on the matter (she's worked on this stuff before also)
> 
> [1] https://github.com/rfbproto/rfbproto/blob/master/rfbproto.rst#72security-types

While I agree this feature could do more, like allow a vnc password + TLS between the proxy and hypervisor, I don't feel it's necessarily useless. From the spec review, my interpretation was that this feature seeks to be an improvement over not being able to have a password at all, so if someone discovered the console URL of another user, they would need to know the password too (one extra layer beyond the token).

I think this feature doesn't get you much if you don't have TLS between the [end user] client and the proxy (since it would be possible for people to extract passwords from the network) but I don't think it's necessarily a non-starter if you don't have TLS between the proxy and the hypervisor. It's certainly best practice to have TLS between the proxy and hypervisor but I could imagine deployers deferring it if the private network between the proxy and hypervisor is much more locked down than the network end users are on (I'm imagining a private cloud scenario).

I definitely agree that the 'vnc' security type should have a clear warning on it in the config help stating that it will *not* encrypt traffic between the proxy and the hypervisor. And I think that addition of the 'X509Vnc' subtype would be a good enhancement in the future so that people could get a vnc password + TLS between the proxy and the hypervisor."}, {'account_id': 31412, 'date': '2021-02-19 09:56:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 31.'}, {'account_id': 31412, 'date': '2021-02-19 10:02:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

It's certainly best practice to have TLS between the proxy and hypervisor but I could imagine deployers deferring it if the private network between the proxy and hypervisor is much more locked down than the network end users are on (I'm imagining a private cloud scenario).

(1 comment)

Okay, I think I've made a mistake in suggesting we switch to VeNCrypt+VNC 😞 There are two connections in play here: client<->proxy and proxy<->server. The '[vnc] auth_schemes' configuration option is currently used to configure the authentication scheme for the latter, the proxy<->server connection, as discussed in the initial spec [1].  My suggestion to use VeNCrypt+VNC would make sense if we wanted to enable password-based auth for proxy<->server but we don't - we want it for the client<->proxy connection. By adding 'vnc' to this list, we were not only removing the ability to configure VeNCrypt authentication for the proxy<->server connection but also changing the meaning of this option to configure authentication for the client<->proxy connection instead. As I've noted inline, 'vnc' is likely perfectly fine for the client<->proxy connection since we already have TLS-encrypted websockets to encrypt that.

I think we need to go back to PS32 or so, undoing the changes to add VeNCrypt to the client<->proxy connection, and instead introduce a new configuration option to configure the auth scheme for the client<->proxy connection. This can either be a list similar to the one we currently use for the proxy<->server connection, '[vnc] auth_schemes' (in which case you should rename '[vnc] auth_schemes' to be less generic - perhaps '[vnc] client_auth_schemes' and '[vnc] server_auth_schemes'?), or a simple boolean. I am assuming that it's possible to use different authentication methods on different backends, meaning we can drop the password for the proxy<->server connection. This seems reasonable given we currently support VeNCrypt for proxy<->server but not client<->proxy.

As an aside, are you testing this? I'm surprised that this current change would work, since it would require support for VeNCrypt in your client and I don't see any code to do the required handshaking with said client. Maybe it was downgrading the connection, but if so were you getting asked for a password?

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/queens/implemented/websocket-proxy-to-host-security.html#other-deployer-impact"}, {'account_id': 31412, 'date': '2021-03-02 02:03:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 37.'}, {'account_id': 31412, 'date': '2021-03-02 05:36:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2021-03-02 06:10:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37:

> Patch Set 36: Code-Review-1
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> Okay, I think I've made a mistake in suggesting we switch to VeNCrypt+VNC 😞 There are two connections in play here: client<->proxy and proxy<->server. The '[vnc] auth_schemes' configuration option is currently used to configure the authentication scheme for the latter, the proxy<->server connection, as discussed in the initial spec [1].  My suggestion to use VeNCrypt+VNC would make sense if we wanted to enable password-based auth for proxy<->server but we don't - we want it for the client<->proxy connection. By adding 'vnc' to this list, we were not only removing the ability to configure VeNCrypt authentication for the proxy<->server connection but also changing the meaning of this option to configure authentication for the client<->proxy connection instead. As I've noted inline, 'vnc' is likely perfectly fine for the client<->proxy connection since we already have TLS-encrypted websockets to encrypt that.

Hm, I think that the 'vnc' scheme in this patch _is_ for the proxy<->server connection. It's making it so that the vnc server running on the guest will require a password challenge [2] for the client (the proxy) to connect to it. And the password the guest's vnc server will use for that challenge is supplied by the user at console create time.

> I think we need to go back to PS32 or so, undoing the changes to add VeNCrypt to the client<->proxy connection, and instead introduce a new configuration option to configure the auth scheme for the client<->proxy connection. This can either be a list similar to the one we currently use for the proxy<->server connection, '[vnc] auth_schemes' (in which case you should rename '[vnc] auth_schemes' to be less generic - perhaps '[vnc] client_auth_schemes' and '[vnc] server_auth_schemes'?), or a simple boolean. I am assuming that it's possible to use different authentication methods on different backends, meaning we can drop the password for the proxy<->server connection. This seems reasonable given we currently support VeNCrypt for proxy<->server but not client<->proxy.

I think what the patch currently has (a 'vnc' choice for the existing [vnc]auth_schemes config option) is the correct thing to do, based on what I said above ^.

> As an aside, are you testing this? I'm surprised that this current change would work, since it would require support for VeNCrypt in your client and I don't see any code to do the required handshaking with said client. Maybe it was downgrading the connection, but if so were you getting asked for a password?

I don't think that VeNCrypt is required for this password feature to work, however it would be best if we could have a tempest test for this. I'm just not sure what/how it would look for connecting to the console for a tempest test to enter the password to the password prompt.

Wenping/Brin, have you looked into adding a tempest test for this feature? Does it seem like it would be possible to add one?

> [1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/queens/implemented/websocket-proxy-to-host-security.html#other-deployer-impact

[2] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6143#section-7.2.2"}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2021-03-02 07:16:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37:

stephenfin, melwitt, whatever, thanks for your explain.
We were returned to PS32, using the VNC password for client<->proxy, and we are testing it and used in our cloud.
As stephenfin point, if we want to promote the security for proxy<->server, may we need to have a new logical for the `[vnc]server_auth_schemes`, and that not we want to do in this patch.



> 
> I don't think that VeNCrypt is required for this password feature to work, however it would be best if we could have a tempest test for this. I'm just not sure what/how it would look for connecting to the console for a tempest test to enter the password to the password prompt.
> 
> Wenping/Brin, have you looked into adding a tempest test for this feature? Does it seem like it would be possible to add one?
> 

We are not familiar with the tempest about your concern, and we looked into the tempest case for VNC, it seems to be satisfied our changes, if possible you can help or guide us to do the tempest."}, {'account_id': 31412, 'date': '2021-03-02 08:38:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37:

Okay, the comments inline could be misleading if not useless, but importantly I'm not able to get this working locally. I've done the following:

1. Deploy DevStack with the TLS and console encryption enabled [1]
2. Create a new server and create a new console token with 'nova get-vnc-console'
3. Ensure I can connect to the console via the browser
4. Modify '/etc/nova/nova_cell1.conf' to set '[vnc] auth_schemes = vnc' instead of 'vencrypt'
5. Restart 'devstack@n-novnc-cell1.service' via 'systemctl'
6. Create a new console token with a patched version of 'nova get-vnc-console' [2]
7. Ensure I can connect to the console via the browser

The final step is failing with the error seen at [3].

So, what am I missing? How is this expected to work? Do we support noVNC? If not, that would suggest this will only work if we bypass the console proxy. I don't think that's what we want to do.

> 
> [1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/803154/
> [2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-novaclient/+/778229
> [3] http://paste.openstack.org/show/803155/

The _think_ the error in [3] is happening in your env because the vnc server running on the instance is requiring auth type 'vencrypt' (which maps to auth type '19' [4]) due to being configured for vnc_tls = 1 in qemu.conf (from deploying with [1]), while the client (proxy) is trying to present 'vnc' (which maps to auth type '2' [5]) after you did step 4.

I think it is like you said earlier, you can't use both 'vencrypt' and 'vnc' [password] at the same time. The deployment setup for this would have to be no TLS between the proxy and instance server. TLS can however be used between the end user client and proxy though.

[4] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0226f9dd630a29c57a97d0fbc7f98250040c42bb/nova/console/rfb/auth.py#L35
[5] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0226f9dd630a29c57a97d0fbc7f98250040c42bb/nova/console/rfb/auth.py#L29"}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2021-03-04 00:19:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37:

> > stephenfin: your steps have no problem. the exception raise from[1], from what i verify, i found the f[2] value depend on the instance has connected the console. the password takes effect after we reboot the guest. as melwitt also says, it is really a problem, we couldnot updateDeviceFlag with `libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_AFFECT_LIVE`[3], it raise exception `libvirt.libvirtError: internal error: unable to execute QEMU command 'set_password': Could not set password` and just update the guest xml config.

I looked into this more today and learned some things about the vnc password feature in qemu.

Looking at a blog post by the author of the feature, Daniel Berrange [4] and the patch emails [5], it shows that the password feature was part of the first steps of adding authentication support for the vnc server in qemu. That is, it is the weaker security option and TLS with 'vencrypt' is stronger. In nova, the stronger option was added awhile back, skipping over the weaker password option.

I am personally not opposed to the idea of adding a weaker option for those who are not ready for TLS between the proxy and vnc server for the guest *but* as I said earlier, I think the fact that a password cannot be set on a live running instance is a problem. Having to hard reboot the guest in order to apply password auth is not a good user experience and I think would cause confusion and a false sense of security for users (if they set a password and believe it is in effect when it is in fact not).

I reached out to Daniel earlier today to ask whether it is expected that we cannot set a password on a running guest and that it must be hard rebooted. He said that it is expected because it implies a change in the auth mechanism. The only way that we could support setting a vnc password without requiring a hard reboot of the guest is if we accepted a vnc password request parameter for server create, so that the guest first gets created with XML containing the vnc password. If a guest already has a vnc password, qemu will allow the password to be changed live, without a hard reboot of the guest.

IMHO adding a vnc password option to server create is (1) too invasive, this feature was intended to be targeted for the get_vnc_console API and (2) we would still have the potential for confusion and false ideas of security if a user for example did not provide a vnc password at server create time but did provide one when they get_vnc_console.

I am sorry to say that I think we are at a stuck state with this feature :(  I can't think of another way around this. If anyone has any other ideas, please share them.

> [1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/622336/37/nova/console/securityproxy/rfb.py#165
> [2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/622336/37/nova/console/securityproxy/rfb.py#138
> [3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/622336/37/nova/virt/libvirt/guest.py#154
[4] https://www.berrange.com/posts/2016/04/01/improving-qemu-security-part-3-securely-passing-in-credentials
[5] https://lists.nongnu.org/archive/html/qemu-devel/2007-07/msg00428.html"}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2021-03-04 01:33:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37:

> 
> I looked into this more today and learned some things about the vnc password feature in qemu.
> 
> Looking at a blog post by the author of the feature, Daniel Berrange [4] and the patch emails [5], it shows that the password feature was part of the first steps of adding authentication support for the vnc server in qemu. That is, it is the weaker security option and TLS with 'vencrypt' is stronger. In nova, the stronger option was added awhile back, skipping over the weaker password option.
> 
> I am personally not opposed to the idea of adding a weaker option for those who are not ready for TLS between the proxy and vnc server for the guest *but* as I said earlier, I think the fact that a password cannot be set on a live running instance is a problem. Having to hard reboot the guest in order to apply password auth is not a good user experience and I think would cause confusion and a false sense of security for users (if they set a password and believe it is in effect when it is in fact not).
> 
> I reached out to Daniel earlier today to ask whether it is expected that we cannot set a password on a running guest and that it must be hard rebooted. He said that it is expected because it implies a change in the auth mechanism. The only way that we could support setting a vnc password without requiring a hard reboot of the guest is if we accepted a vnc password request parameter for server create, so that the guest first gets created with XML containing the vnc password. If a guest already has a vnc password, qemu will allow the password to be changed live, without a hard reboot of the guest.
> 
> IMHO adding a vnc password option to server create is (1) too invasive, this feature was intended to be targeted for the get_vnc_console API and (2) we would still have the potential for confusion and false ideas of security if a user for example did not provide a vnc password at server create time but did provide one when they get_vnc_console.
> 

Yes, I looked back for this spec [a], in this patch we were propsoed to support VNC password in ``server create`` API, and that can support changing the password without hard reboot, but the disadvantages are as you mentioned above.

In the [b] PS21, we talked in IRC at nova meeting, and decide to use get_vnc_console API

[a] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/623120/19
[b] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/623120/21

> I am sorry to say that I think we are at a stuck state with this feature :(  I can't think of another way around this. If anyone has any other ideas, please share them.

As you said above, if there is no good approach to resolve the "hard reboot issue with reset VNC password", this feature may need to be prohibited.

> 
> > [1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/622336/37/nova/console/securityproxy/rfb.py#165
> > [2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/622336/37/nova/console/securityproxy/rfb.py#138
> > [3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/622336/37/nova/virt/libvirt/guest.py#154
> [4] https://www.berrange.com/posts/2016/04/01/improving-qemu-security-part-3-securely-passing-in-credentials
> [5] https://lists.nongnu.org/archive/html/qemu-devel/2007-07/msg00428.html'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2021-03-04 03:24:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37:

Warning: I doubt this is a good idea, but I realized a way I think this could be done without the problem of a false sense of security is if we added a [vnc] option for the compute node that was something like 'require_password' which if set to True, would create all VMs with a blank default password. This would result in all vnc console connections being rejected by qemu until a password is set via the get_vnc_console API. One possible problem with this: if the rejected connection does not tell the user why they are being rejected and that they need to set a vnc password, it would cause a lot of user confusion. I haven't tried to connect to a console that has a blank password, but when I tried entering a wrong password in my testing, it did not tell me I had a wrong password. It just said that the remote connection was closed.

Care would also need to be taken to handle the scenario where the operator has set [vnc]require_password=True but then changes their mind and unsets it later or sets it to False. To handle this case we would need to reject get_vnc_console API requests with a 400 that include a password request param if the guest XML does not already contain the 'passwd' element. I _think_ this might be possible because the get_vnc_console API to the compute node is a synchronous call. By rejecting password setting requests for VMs that were not created when [vnc]require_password was True, users cannot get in the situation where they think they set a password but it is not actually in effect."}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2021-03-04 06:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37:

Get the old discuss with the vnc/spice password from Redhar bugzilla:

In order to keep the virtualization products consistent 
1. if we don't set password to a guest started without vnc/spice passwd , please prompt the info "The requested feature is not supported"
2. if we don't support clear password from the guest started with vnc/spice passwd, please prompt the info "The requested feature is not supported". Then we can file the virt-manager bug to make the GNU tools have the same response . 

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=731685

As description above, this is a common issue.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-03-04 14:35:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37:

two issue with this 
openstack is not an enterpise virutualisation product so we shoudl not be trying to make it consitned with entrerpise virutalisation stacks. its a cloud platform.
second issue is that was rejected by libvirt as wontfix since after almost 5 years since
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=731685#c5 was posted no one actully agreed followed up with this as a real usecase that was needed. the orignal qemu feature request was also closted as wont-fix https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=768423 because the upstream patch was nackd
https://lists.nongnu.org/archive/html/qemu-devel/2015-10/msg03544.html

so i dont think RHEV/ovirt can do this either without a guest reboot.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-03-04 14:47:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37: Code-Review-1

> Patch Set 37:
> 
> Warning: I doubt this is a good idea, but I realized a way I think this could be done without the problem of a false sense of security is if we added a [vnc] option for the compute node that was something like 'require_password' which if set to True, would create all VMs with a blank default password. This would result in all vnc console connections being rejected by qemu until a password is set via the get_vnc_console API.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[sean] if we could set the  passwoard to the empty string and make this transparent to the enduser i might be ok with something like this but if setting require_password would prevent the console connect then to me that is config driven api behavior which i am much less ok with. i generally dont like per host config options like this as they can have implication for live migration. in this case i am not sure why the correct behavior would be when live migrating an instance without a password but with require_password=False to one with a require_password=True. if it really prevented conenction to me that allone makes this unworkable as user would sudenly not have console access if an admin migrated there vm.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


 One possible problem with this: if the rejected connection does not tell the user why they are being rejected and that they need to set a vnc password, it would cause a lot of user confusion. I haven't tried to connect to a console that has a blank password, but when I tried entering a wrong password in my testing, it did not tell me I had a wrong password. It just said that the remote connection was closed.
> 
> Care would also need to be taken to handle the scenario where the operator has set [vnc]require_password=True but then changes their mind and unsets it later or sets it to False. To handle this case we would need to reject get_vnc_console API requests with a 400 that include a password request param if the guest XML does not already contain the 'passwd' element. I _think_ this might be possible because the get_vnc_console API to the compute node is a synchronous call. By rejecting password setting requests for VMs that were not created when [vnc]require_password was True, users cannot get in the situation where they think they set a password but it is not actually in effect.


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[sean]i think we would need triat or some other logic at the schduler level to proably supprot the host option. Could we just return a message that say you must hard reboot for the console passwoard to take effect ro allow passing a reboot flag in the api call? this feels like very late to be redsiging this but i think the only way to move forward would be to have the set passward call do a hard reboot or just documenmt this as a requirement for the user. neither are good option form a ux perspective.
given the limited utility of this feature im beinging to think we need to pause it and reasses if it should be added. the current limit on password lenght means it relitivly easy to brought force and the fact we are not storing the password in barbican or otherswise encypting it on the nova db makes me uncomfortable. if we add in the ux issue relatedto needing a hard reboot i think this deserve more tought before we proceed. 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------"}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2021-03-04 21:28:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37:

> [sean] if we could set the  passwoard to the empty string and make this transparent to the enduser i might be ok with something like this but if setting require_password would prevent the console connect then to me that is config driven api behavior which i am much less ok with. i generally dont like per host config options like this as they can have implication for live migration. in this case i am not sure why the correct behavior would be when live migrating an instance without a password but with require_password=False to one with a require_password=True. if it really prevented conenction to me that allone makes this unworkable as user would sudenly not have console access if an admin migrated there vm.

Yeah, I agree something like that would feel like a config-driven API behavior. I had been thinking _maybe_ it would be similar to other APIs that will not work depending on which virt driver is configured. Example from a quick look in the code, the trigger crash dump API [1], it returns a 400 if the virt driver does not support it.

I think for live migration it should just keep what it has in its XML: if it has a password, keep it, if it does not have a password, leave it alone. The option would be better named 'require_password_for_new_instances', that is what I was thinking.

> [sean]i think we would need triat or some other logic at the schduler level to proably supprot the host option. Could we just return a message that say you must hard reboot for the console passwoard to take effect ro allow passing a reboot flag in the api call? this feels like very late to be redsiging this but i think the only way to move forward would be to have the set passward call do a hard reboot or just documenmt this as a requirement for the user. neither are good option form a ux perspective.
> given the limited utility of this feature im beinging to think we need to pause it and reasses if it should be added. the current limit on password lenght means it relitivly easy to brought force and the fact we are not storing the password in barbican or otherswise encypting it on the nova db makes me uncomfortable. if we add in the ux issue relatedto needing a hard reboot i think this deserve more tought before we proceed. 

I am -1 on the idea of doing a hard reboot if a password is passed in get_vnc_console, I could easily see that being an unpleasant surprise for a user. Also -1 on returning a message saying you must hard reboot. I think both are a poor user experience as you point out. I think if we are going to support vnc passwords, it needs to be an easy/seamless experience for users, and so far I am not seeing that there is any user-friendly way to provide it.

The closest I could come up with is what I described earlier, but it does feel like config-driven API behavior and having a vnc console default to "reject all" if the user has not set a password yet is a poor experience too. I guess for the latter issue we could detect lack of a password in the proxy and give the user an error message indicating they need to reset their password in order to connect. That still leaves us with what might be considered config-driven API behavior.

I agree that I think there are too many problems here to solve this late in the process and without wider discussion. 😞

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=trigger-crash-dump-in-server-detail#trigger-crash-dump-in-server'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2021-03-05 01:19:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37: Code-Review-1

(b)with server create API, it's too intrusive to the VM system;
(c)with config-driven API behavior, looks better than before options, but it's also not have a good UX for users, the same as give the warning with exceptions.

I think we have to stop working hard on this, as melwitt said, we need an extensive, systematic discussion, how about put this to Xena PTG?"}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2021-03-08 08:23:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-04 14:20:13.000000000', 'message': 'Add rfb.VNC support for novncproxy

Change-Id: Ib6193bffc2922af1f79842cb2ea01b85c2e2b3c5
'}, {'created': '2018-12-06 12:25:23.000000000', 'message': 'Add rfb.VNC support for novncproxy

As part of bp/nova-support-webvnc-with-password-anthentication,
works as follows are done to ensure novncproxy can support rfb.VNC:
(1) providing novncproxy `vnc` option in auth schemes list by
extending `nova.conf.vnc` and `nova.console.rfb.auths`;
(2) adapt the security type negotiation in `nova.console.security
proxy.rfb` to provide compatibility for rfc.VNC;

Note that, why item (2) works needed:
In current version, novncproxy tells tenant sock to use hardcoded
`vnc.AuthType.NONE` when serving as mediator between client and vnc
server. However, noVNC client provides native support for `vnc.Auth
Type.VNC` with password security handshake handle, and thus, a rfb.
VNC auth scheme is implemented with no-ops `security_handshake`
leaving noVNC/websockify to do the stuff.

Change-Id: Ib6193bffc2922af1f79842cb2ea01b85c2e2b3c5
'}, {'created': '2019-05-17 05:25:40.000000000', 'message': 'Add rfb.VNC support for novncproxy

As part of bp/nova-support-webvnc-with-password-anthentication,
works as follows are done to ensure novncproxy can support rfb.VNC:
(1) providing novncproxy `vnc` option in auth schemes list by
extending `nova.conf.vnc` and `nova.console.rfb.auths`;
(2) adapt the security type negotiation in `nova.console.security
proxy.rfb` to provide compatibility for rfc.VNC;

Note that, why item (2) works needed:
In current version, novncproxy tells tenant sock to use hardcoded
`vnc.AuthType.NONE` when serving as mediator between client and vnc
server. However, noVNC client provides native support for `vnc.Auth
Type.VNC` with password security handshake handle, and thus, a rfb.
VNC auth scheme is implemented with no-ops `security_handshake`
leaving noVNC/websockify to do the stuff.

commit_message:
Nova supports password encrypted VNC

Today one user can simply kick/steal another user session from an
instance just by connecting to it. This patch aims at providing a safer
remote console with password authentication, it would solve above issue
(once it implements spice support).

Co-Authored-By: Brin Zhang <zhangbailin@inspur.com>
Co-Authored-By: Wenping Song <songwenping@inspur.com>

Blueprint: nova-support-webvnc-with-password-anthentication
Change-Id: Ib6193bffc2922af1f79842cb2ea01b85c2e2b3c5

subject: Improve parsing of cron schedule
messages: [{'account_id': 8992, 'date': '2021-08-17 18:29:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 33717, 'date': '2021-08-17 22:23:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1\n\nLGTM'}, {'account_id': 31289, 'date': '2021-08-18 09:47:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-08-17 18:29:38.000000000', 'message': "Improve parsing of cron schedule

Improving the parsing of the cron schedule for /etc/cron/rabbitmq-stats.
The code makes assumptions that the user in the cron entry will be the
root user, which is generally safe as that's what the charm applied.
However, the parsing is brittle in that it depends on the 'root' string
in the entry. This changes the code so that the cron timer spec is
stripped out based on the column entries in the file.

Change-Id: I2d573e8942e840e0e5376f1537a2a3373fea3db8
Fixes-Bug: #1939702
"}]
commit_message:
Improve parsing of cron schedule

Improving the parsing of the cron schedule for /etc/cron/rabbitmq-stats.
The code makes assumptions that the user in the cron entry will be the
root user, which is generally safe as that's what the charm applied.
However, the parsing is brittle in that it depends on the 'root' string
in the entry. This changes the code so that the cron timer spec is
stripped out based on the column entries in the file.

Change-Id: I2d573e8942e840e0e5376f1537a2a3373fea3db8
Fixes-Bug: #1939702

During migration from OVS to OVN it can happen that gateway ports are
scheduled to a different gateway chassis when Neutron is running. This
patch doesn't fail in such case. The migration procedure runs the db
sync twice in a row so it should be good to not perform any action when
this happens and let the next migration handle that.

Change-Id: I28a4a5fef20d5049f4887d43006947b434de3d78
Closes-Bug: #1939704

commit_message:
ovn: Don't fail db-sync if port binding changes

During migration from OVS to OVN it can happen that gateway ports are
scheduled to a different gateway chassis when Neutron is running. This
patch doesn't fail in such case. The migration procedure runs the db
sync twice in a row so it should be good to not perform any action when
this happens and let the next migration handle that.

Change-Id: I28a4a5fef20d5049f4887d43006947b434de3d78
Closes-Bug: #1939704
Signed-off-by: Jakub Libosvar <libosvar@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 9e0c075bf169ed6f3d768cf23be6f47aeae0f98e)

commit_message:
Remove now useless sudo call for port check

Back then, the "sudo" was needed because healthchecks were running as
root, using a paunch created systemd unit/timer calling "podman exec
--user root".

Now that we're using native healthchecks, we can get rid of the sudo
call, since it's already using as the intended user.

Closes-Bug: #1940068

Change-Id: I7eaabc91005952aa956456944c46224f08f4c7f8
(cherry picked from commit 36a7a4d093470ffe5d970cc288da292714b48f2a)

commit_message:
Remove now useless sudo call for port check

Back then, the "sudo" was needed because healthchecks were running as
root, using a paunch created systemd unit/timer calling "podman exec
--user root".

Now that we're using native healthchecks, we can get rid of the sudo
call, since it's already using as the intended user.

Closes-Bug: #1940068

Change-Id: I7eaabc91005952aa956456944c46224f08f4c7f8
(cherry picked from commit 36a7a4d093470ffe5d970cc288da292714b48f2a)

commit_message:
Replace deprecated arguments of RequestContext

The following arguments of the RequestContext class are deprecated
since oslo.context 2.18[1].
 user          : renamed to user_id
 tenant        : renamed to project_id
 domain        : renamed to domain_id
 user_domain   : renamed to user_domain_id
 project_domain: renamed to project_domain_id

Change-Id: I29d901a8fa96acf55dc53f826a501a3109c0c7af

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-10 13:14:07.000000000', 'message': 'Mask sensitive data when logging action results

When passwords or other sensible data is returned by a Action, they can
be logged by Mistral. This change uses the password masking
functionality used in mistral-lib and privided by oslo-utils.

This function uses the standard cut_repr method in mistral-lib, which
also means the output is more standardised.

Related-Bug: #1850843
Change-Id: I01bf47f7a83102a1a16b15bf0bbb4021707e11fe
(cherry picked from commit a25c8fab881decff0e61deffe1895f1d99132f9f)
(cherry picked from commit 4d3ef8887fb765c9edd36f62cc66904aff4c1b0e)
'}, {'created': '2020-06-17 08:34:06.000000000', 'message': 'Mask sensitive data when logging action results

When passwords or other sensible data is returned by a Action, they can

commit_message:
Mask sensitive data when logging action results

When passwords or other sensible data is returned by a Action, they can
be logged by Mistral. This change uses the password masking
functionality used in mistral-lib and privided by oslo-utils.

This function uses the standard cut_repr method in mistral-lib, which
also means the output is more standardised.

Related-Bug: #1850843
Change-Id: I01bf47f7a83102a1a16b15bf0bbb4021707e11fe
(cherry picked from commit a25c8fab881decff0e61deffe1895f1d99132f9f)
(cherry picked from commit 4d3ef8887fb765c9edd36f62cc66904aff4c1b0e)

commit_message:
Allow watch_frr options to be set and support frr-8.0

frr-8.0 does not need any watchfrr options set.
Let's still allow some customizability in case we'll need to
tweak them one day.

Tested on a BGP deployment.

Change-Id: I5943d7b00634c3d733e3e38b4ed247ccac253e27

commit_message:
Supports Pagination and Sorting for agent List

Neutron-lib patch defined with new  API extension to support "sort_key"
argument and fix was merged.

Change-Id: I08227fac7001d526ae6ffdaa9a1e32fd0817a472
Closes-Bug: #1877254

commit_message:
Use explicit "dict_or_nodata" validation for "external_gateway_info"

That API definition will be used during the policy check to create the
needed rule for each internal GW info element, specifically with the
external network fixed IPs. Only the owner of the external network or
the administrator can create fixed IPs on the external network.

Change-Id: Ia70485ed7713436dd6433ed39ae721500dbed7dd
Closes-Bug: #1940224

2021-04-27 02:27:38.345 316196 ERROR openstack [-] Unable to establish connection to https://192.168.24.2:13989/v2/executions: ('Connection aborted.', BrokenPipeError(32, 'Broken pipe')): keystoneauth1.exceptions.connection.ConnectFailure: Unable to establish connection to https://192.168.24.2:13989/v2/executions: ('Connection aborted.', BrokenPipeError(32, 'Broken pipe'))
2021-04-27 02:27:38.346 316196 INFO osc_lib.shell [-] END return value: 1

The above means that port 13989, which haproxy redirects to port 8989 (mistral-server api), had a diccup and mistral-api returned connection
refused for a short moment. This happened when we tried to create the workflow execution.

In the same vein as Ie08f3bc7c7cd7796f067a9ee0a99c017a5567ea2 ("Make workflow monitoring more resilient")
let's try and add some resilience when we create the workflow execution and not only when we monitor it.

Change-Id: I588bf89ec7cc44f7ba7c96fe9ce55bbbc2b956d3

2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     return self.session.post(self.base_url + url, data=body, **options)

2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     raise exceptions.ConnectFailure(msg)
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge keystoneauth1.exceptions.connection.ConnectFailure: Unable to establish connection to https://192.168.24.2:13989/v2/executions: ('Connection aborted.', BrokenPipeError(32, 'Broken pipe'))
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge
2021-04-27 02:27:38.345 316196 ERROR openstack [-] Unable to establish connection to https://192.168.24.2:13989/v2/executions: ('Connection aborted.', BrokenPipeError(32, 'Broken pipe')): keystoneauth1.exceptions.connection.ConnectFailure: Unable to establish connection to https://192.168.24.2:13989/v2/executions: ('Connection aborted.', BrokenPipeError(32, 'Broken pipe'))
2021-04-27 02:27:38.346 316196 INFO osc_lib.shell [-] END return value: 1

The above means that port 13989, which haproxy redirects to port 8989 (mistral-server api), had a diccup and mistral-api returned connection
refused for a short moment. This happened when we tried to create the workflow execution.

In the same vein as Ie08f3bc7c7cd7796f067a9ee0a99c017a5567ea2 ("Make workflow monitoring more resilient")
let's try and add some resilience when we create the workflow execution and not only when we monitor it.

Change-Id: I588bf89ec7cc44f7ba7c96fe9ce55bbbc2b956d3

commit_message:
WIP Retry the start_workflow a few times

I had a converge run (post minor-update) fail with the following
traceback:

2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge [-] Exception occured while running the command: keystoneauth1.exceptions.connection.ConnectFailure: Unable to establish connection to https://192.168.24.2:13989/v2/executions: ('Connection aborted.', BrokenPipeError(32, 'Broken pipe'))
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge Traceback (most recent call last):
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 600, in urlopen
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     chunked=chunked)
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 354, in _make_request
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     conn.request(method, url, **httplib_request_kw)
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/http/client.py", line 1269, in request
...
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tripleoclient/workflows/deployment.py", line 204, in get_hosts_and_enable_ssh_admin
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     enable_ssh_timeout, enable_ssh_port_timeout)
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tripleoclient/workflows/deployment.py", line 290, in enable_ssh_admin
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     workflow_input=workflow_input
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tripleoclient/workflows/base.py", line 40, in start_workflow
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     workflow_input=workflow_input
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/mistralclient/api/v2/executions.py", line 61, in create
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     return self._create('/executions', data)
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/mistralclient/api/base.py", line 144, in _create
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     resp = self.http_client.post(url, data, headers)
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/mistralclient/api/httpclient.py", line 54, in decorator
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     resp = func(self, *args, **kwargs)
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/mistralclient/api/httpclient.py", line 120, in post
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     return self.session.post(self.base_url + url, data=body, **options)
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/keystoneauth1/session.py", line 1124, in post
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     return self.request(url, 'POST', **kwargs)
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/keystoneauth1/session.py", line 906, in request
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     resp = send(**kwargs)
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge   File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/keystoneauth1/session.py", line 1013, in _send_request
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge     raise exceptions.ConnectFailure(msg)
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge keystoneauth1.exceptions.connection.ConnectFailure: Unable to establish connection to https://192.168.24.2:13989/v2/executions: ('Connection aborted.', BrokenPipeError(32, 'Broken pipe'))
2021-04-27 02:27:38.334 316196 ERROR tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_update.UpdateConverge
2021-04-27 02:27:38.345 316196 ERROR openstack [-] Unable to establish connection to https://192.168.24.2:13989/v2/executions: ('Connection aborted.', BrokenPipeError(32, 'Broken pipe')): keystoneauth1.exceptions.connection.ConnectFailure: Unable to establish connection to https://192.168.24.2:13989/v2/executions: ('Connection aborted.', BrokenPipeError(32, 'Broken pipe'))
2021-04-27 02:27:38.346 316196 INFO osc_lib.shell [-] END return value: 1

The above means that port 13989, which haproxy redirects to port 8989 (mistral-server api), had a diccup and mistral-api returned connection
refused for a short moment. This happened when we tried to create the workflow execution.

In the same vein as Ie08f3bc7c7cd7796f067a9ee0a99c017a5567ea2 ("Make workflow monitoring more resilient")
let's try and add some resilience when we create the workflow execution and not only when we monitor it.

Change-Id: I588bf89ec7cc44f7ba7c96fe9ce55bbbc2b956d3

commit_message:
Replace oslo_utils.fnmatch with fnmatch

The oslo_utils.fnmatch module was added to solve an issue in py2.7 but
it is no longer required because py2.7 is no longer supported.
The module was deprecated since oslo.utils 4.9.1[1] and the stdlib's
fnmatch module should be used instead.

[1] 4c893c92f551c9dd2a7cfbe7ae8171ad8139df0b

Change-Id: I95535adeb45363500b3ed9729bb61cb4308d23b9

messages: [{'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-08-17 16:41:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-08-17 19:25:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2021-08-18 06:43:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nThank you Harald!'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-08-17 16:41:18.000000000', 'message': 'Document ``--skip-nodes-and-networks``

When not using the *all-in-one* aproach, i.e manually
provisioning networks, virtual IPs and baremetal nodes
using the individual commands. The ``--skip-nodes-and-networks``
argument should be used with the ``overcloud deploy``
command so that the steps are not redundantly repeated
since the ``overcloud deploy`` command defaults to the
*all-in-one* approach.

Change-Id: I488a1285c9616d016aa4a65fa67b333875100b66
'}]
commit_message:
Document ``--skip-nodes-and-networks``

When not using the *all-in-one* aproach, i.e manually
provisioning networks, virtual IPs and baremetal nodes
using the individual commands. The ``--skip-nodes-and-networks``
argument should be used with the ``overcloud deploy``
command so that the steps are not redundantly repeated
since the ``overcloud deploy`` command defaults to the
*all-in-one* approach.

Change-Id: I488a1285c9616d016aa4a65fa67b333875100b66

messages:
[{'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2021-08-17 13:55:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-08-17 14:54:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

No, we can't remove those.
Can you open a bug with details on the commands used to deploy when hitting this issue?

I have blocked the backport of I8e0f2762d744b21ec1555faa1e9bbe6e2d00f67b for now."}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2021-08-17 14:59:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'll do a new LP tomorrow with some more details, files and all - I won't re-deploy today since it's late. Thanks for checking in and blocking the backport in the meanwhile!"}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-08-17 15:36:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Upstream job's are using the '--skip-nodes-and-networks' parameter in the 'openstack overcloud deploy'  command. I think the problem here is that you are deploying networks and VIPs using the separate commands, and then 'overcloud deploy' command does the same steps and when it is adding the environments internally these registry entries are protected.

We may just want to update the docs to highlight that '--skip-nodes-and-networks' is required when not doing it as "all-in-one" with the 'overclou deploy' command. I.e at step 9 in this doc, https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/custom_networks.html#id1'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-08-17 16:44:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Upstream job's are using the '--skip-nodes-and-networks' parameter in the 'openstack overcloud deploy'  command. I think the problem here is that you are deploying networks and VIPs using the separate commands, and then 'overcloud deploy' command does the same steps and when it is adding the environments internally these registry entries are protected.
> 
> We may just want to update the docs to highlight that '--skip-nodes-and-networks' is required when not doing it as "all-in-one" with the 'overclou deploy' command. I.e at step 9 in this doc, https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/custom_networks.html#id1

I proposed a doc patch: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-docs/+/804893

I do wonder if we should relax the override protection to only error the deployment if the used override is actually using a different key and value compared to the internal one. Currently it will error just based on the resource registry key being present.'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2021-08-18 06:37:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> > Patch Set 1:
> > 
> > Upstream job's are using the '--skip-nodes-and-networks' parameter in the 'openstack overcloud deploy'  command. I think the problem here is that you are deploying networks and VIPs using the separate commands, and then 'overcloud deploy' command does the same steps and when it is adding the environments internally these registry entries are protected.
> > 
> > We may just want to update the docs to highlight that '--skip-nodes-and-networks' is required when not doing it as "all-in-one" with the 'overclou deploy' command. I.e at step 9 in this doc, https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/custom_networks.html#id1
> 
> I proposed a doc patch: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-docs/+/804893
> 
> I do wonder if we should relax the override protection to only error the deployment if the used override is actually using a different key and value compared to the internal one. Currently it will error just based on the resource registry key being present.

Hey Harald,

Thanks for the extended explanation! This new parameter also needs to exist in the tripleo-operator-ansible, else we'll face some other issues (I'm using the operator, and it doesn't seem to propose that param yet - I'll propose a patch shortly).

Now, regarding the "relax override protection": maybe? Not really sure about the potential misused this can introduce. I'm all for strict check (and proper doc ;)) - sooo... Up to you I'd say.'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2021-08-18 06:38:18.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Change isn't something we want, read Harald extended answers and explanation"}]

commit_message:
Remove specific resource_registry

Following I8e0f2762d744b21ec1555faa1e9bbe6e2d00f67b, it seems the
injected resources are hitting the Protected Resource filter, leading to
a failed OC deployment.

Change-Id: Ib4bc27ee60ef22815b0c63d8885e397406909129

commit_message:
Dropping explicit unicode literal

In python 3, all strings are considered as unicode string.

This patch drops the explicit unicode literal (u'...')
or (u"..") appearances from the unicode strings.

Change-Id: I3183f807181e0bcf1655c3dbab5106e9c61910ac

commit_message:
Stop configuring install_command in tox.

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value.

Change-Id: I9b84a078e93a0988081724df6947bc60ed1ddffd

and Stop configuring install_command in tox.

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

commit_message:
Change whitelist to allowlist in tox

This patch replace tox's whitelist_externals by allowlist_externals
and Stop configuring install_command in tox.

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value.

commit_message:
Dropping explicit unicode literal

In python 3, all strings are considered as unicode string.

This patch drops the explicit unicode literal (u'...')
or (u"..") appearances from the unicode strings.

Change-Id: Idbb9b3afa63165c1340429161e127e1ff58c66cf

commit_message:
Fix GH PRs build with Ansible install

After I4f9f3f13346761d3dec35844234cb6ae03ad4107 was merged the
build fails because we don't have ansible installed. It was
installed before in undercloud-setup role later.
Install ansible as a dependency for GH PRs building of collections.
Change-Id: I5681fe386a85643365847e27ff4a803ba43a633a

commit_message:
Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: I88a05dfd99fbca043f25b5ddce7663467699e69b

commit_message:
Remove deny list check from cli-enable-ssh-admin.yaml

The check for denied hosts in cli-enable-ssh-admin.yaml is removed
because it is redundant. The hosts are already removed before the
playbook is called by tripleoclient.utils.get_overcloud_hosts.

Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-08-17 09:53:26.000000000', 'message': 'Remove now useless sudo call for port check

Back then, the "sudo" was needed because healthchecks were running as
root, using a paunch created systemd unit/timer calling "podman exec
--user root".

Now that we're using native healthchecks, we can get rid of the sudo
call, since it's already using as the intended user.

Closes-Bug: #1940068

Change-Id: I7eaabc91005952aa956456944c46224f08f4c7f8
'}]
commit_message:
Remove now useless sudo call for port check

Back then, the "sudo" was needed because healthchecks were running as
root, using a paunch created systemd unit/timer calling "podman exec
--user root".

Now that we're using native healthchecks, we can get rid of the sudo
call, since it's already using as the intended user.

Closes-Bug: #1940068

Change-Id: I7eaabc91005952aa956456944c46224f08f4c7f8

commit_message:
Fix ceph-provisioner rbd-healer error

This patchset fixes the following error which was recently introduced
by changing the cephcsi image version to v3.4.0:

E0816 18:37:30.966684   62307 rbd_healer.go:131] list volumeAttachments failed, err: volumeattachments.storage.k8s.io is forbidden: User "system:serviceaccount:ceph:clcp-ucp-ceph-provisioners-ceph-rbd-csi-nodeplugin" cannot list resource "volumeattachments" in API group "storage.k8s.io" at the cluster scope
E0816 18:37:30.966758   62307 driver.go:208] healer had failures, err volumeattachments.storage.k8s.io is forbidden: User "system:serviceaccount:ceph:clcp-ucp-ceph-provisioners-ceph-rbd-csi-nodeplugin" cannot list resource "volumeattachments" in API group "storage.k8s.io" at the cluster scope

Change-Id: Ia7cc61cf1df6690f25408b7aa8797e51d1c516ff

commit_message:
Add enforce_scope setting support for Glance

Glance started moving to new RBAC and glance-tempest-plugin
and Tempest need to set few configuration to enable the
scope checks on glance side and so does on Temepst side to tell
glance is ready with scope checks so that test can be run with
scoped token.

Change-Id: I09f513d08212bc80a3a86a750b29b1c6625d2f89

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-08-16 13:55:57.000000000', 'message': 'Load options from the castellan library

Currently Glance relies on the castellan library for encryption, but
the option for the library have been missing from glance-api.conf .
This change ensures options from the castellan library are rendered
into glance-api.conf by the oslo-config-generator command.

Closes-Bug: #1940090
Change-Id: I5b9459dfc3060ea40272d13f21ae87ff4ade64c5
'}]
commit_message:
Load options from the castellan library

Currently Glance relies on the castellan library for encryption, but
the option for the library have been missing from glance-api.conf .
This change ensures options from the castellan library are rendered
into glance-api.conf by the oslo-config-generator command.

Closes-Bug: #1940090
Change-Id: I5b9459dfc3060ea40272d13f21ae87ff4ade64c5

commit_message:
[Pure Storage] Resolve missing provider_id issue (PowerVC)

In PowerVC, cloning of multiple volumes fails due to the
provider_id not being populated correctly for a volume.

Change-Id: Ib08a0561aa404a7aee41b23ec5d30f9f52096687
Closes-Bug: #1938579
(cherry picked from commit f67eae51f93ea05e9cd8f956e5aef2b3bf84d7db)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-08-02 12:32:39.000000000', 'message': "[rbd] Fix create encrypted volume from snapshot

Usually the source volume would be the same size or smaller
than the destination volume and they must share the same
volume-type. In particular, when the destination volume is
same size as the source volume, creating an encrypted volume
from a snapshot of an encrypted volume truncates the data in
the new volume.

In order to fix this the RBD workflow would be something
like this:
A source luks volume would be 1026M, we write some data
and create a snap from it. We like to create a new luks
volume from a snapshot so the create_volume_from_snapshot()
method performs a RBD clone first and then a resize if needed.

In addition the _clone() method creates a clone
(copy-on-write child) of the parent snapshot. Object size
will be identical to that of the parent image unless specified
(we don't in cinder) so size will be the same as the parent
snapshot.

If the desired size of the destination luks volume is 1G the
create_volume_from_snapshot() won't perform any resize and
will be 1026M as the parent. This solves bug #1922408 because
we don't force it to resize and because of that we don't
truncate the data anymore.

The second case scenario is when we would like to increase
the size of the destination volume. As far as I can tell this
won't face the encryption header problem but we still need to
calculate the difference size to provide the size that the
user is expecting.

That's why the fix proposed calculate the new_size based on:
size difference = desired size - size of source volume
new size = current size + size difference

Closes-Bug: #1922408
Co-Authored-By: Sofia Enriquez <lsofia.enriquez@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I220b5e3b01d115262a8b1dd45758f0531aea0edf
(cherry picked from commit cf1c5252965e731d77af503529ca42e269c305c6)
"}]
commit_message:
[rbd] Fix create encrypted volume from snapshot

Usually the source volume would be the same size or smaller
than the destination volume and they must share the same
volume-type. In particular, when the destination volume is
same size as the source volume, creating an encrypted volume
from a snapshot of an encrypted volume truncates the data in
the new volume.

In order to fix this the RBD workflow would be something
like this:
A source luks volume would be 1026M, we write some data
and create a snap from it. We like to create a new luks
volume from a snapshot so the create_volume_from_snapshot()
method performs a RBD clone first and then a resize if needed.

In addition the _clone() method creates a clone
(copy-on-write child) of the parent snapshot. Object size
will be identical to that of the parent image unless specified
(we don't in cinder) so size will be the same as the parent
snapshot.

If the desired size of the destination luks volume is 1G the
create_volume_from_snapshot() won't perform any resize and
will be 1026M as the parent. This solves bug #1922408 because
we don't force it to resize and because of that we don't
truncate the data anymore.

The second case scenario is when we would like to increase
the size of the destination volume. As far as I can tell this
won't face the encryption header problem but we still need to
calculate the difference size to provide the size that the
user is expecting.

That's why the fix proposed calculate the new_size based on:
size difference = desired size - size of source volume
new size = current size + size difference

Closes-Bug: #1922408
Co-Authored-By: Sofia Enriquez <lsofia.enriquez@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I220b5e3b01d115262a8b1dd45758f0531aea0edf

commit_message:
tripleo_push_artifacts: fix argument parsing

Fix a logic inversion during argument checking which
causes push_artifacts to fail if only one argument is passed
to the module.

Closes-Bug: #1940294
Change-Id: Ib179fa3cfe057ed67b8b791a3ff62dbcc12ed257

commit_message:
TRAIN-ONLY Fix overcloud support report for T

We use Mistral for this in Queens. But in Train,
we can't do the same thing. This change will backport
the Ansible playbook used in Ussuri.

Change-Id: If8f27a1388b4b4718ba3c23eaca7ff2546713f4f

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-03 13:34:37.000000000', 'message': 'DNM WIP Trying to fix two-node job

Change-Id: I24976e93e9ea8f7f50c9da014c2627965512893c
'}, {'created': '2021-02-03 16:36:47.000000000', 'message': "Fix two-node job configuration

Two-node job was failing because devstack tried to compile the
test_server.go file on controller2.
controller2 doesn't have tempest installed, but octavia-tempest-plugin
was installed. The compilation step was failing and is not necessary
there.

Change-Id: I24976e93e9ea8f7f50c9da014c2627965512893c
"}, {'created': '2021-02-08 08:16:50.000000000', 'message': 'Fix two-node job configuration

Two-node job was failing because devstack tried to compile the
test_server.go file on controller2.
controller2 doesn't have tempest installed, but octavia-tempest-plugin
was installed. The compilation step was failing and is not necessary
there.

Fix octavia-v2-act-stdby-dsvm-scenario-two-node definition, overrides
were not applied.

The "zuul_copy_output" option under host-vars overrides base
"zuul_copy_output". This means only barely a handful of log files are
copied. Fix this by using "host_copy_output" option to combine both log
file lists.

Co-Authored-By: Carlos Goncalves <cgoncalves@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I24976e93e9ea8f7f50c9da014c2627965512893c

commit_message:
Fix two-node job configuration

Two-node job was failing because devstack tried to compile the
test_server.go file on controller2.
controller2 doesn't have tempest installed, but octavia-tempest-plugin
was installed. The compilation step was failing and is not necessary
there.

Fix octavia-v2-act-stdby-dsvm-scenario-two-node definition, overrides
were not applied.
Fix the "zuul_copy_output" section.

Move to ML2/OVN backend.

Co-Authored-By: Carlos Goncalves <cgoncalves@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I24976e93e9ea8f7f50c9da014c2627965512893c

commit_message:
[EM releases] Move non-voting jobs to the experimental queue

During the CI meeting we agreed that non-voting jobs in the branches
which are in Extened Maintenance (EM) phase should be moved to from
the check to the experimental queue.

This patch is doing exactly that.

Change-Id: I775af9673e8fdbc70b439d92b355bbc00cd27432

commit_message:
Fixes test_user_update_own_password test cleanup problem (New password cannnot be identical to a previous password)

This test's cleanup method needs to have security compliance feature enabled to take effect. Because it uses constant which is valid only if it's enabled.

That's why this test has to be skipped unless Security compliance is available.

Closes-Bug: 1934249
Change-Id: I006fdf233b0af20625e41beb2a4c63109fcdcb17

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-14 11:00:10.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Do not destroy volume secrets during _hard_reboot

Ia2007bc63ef09931ea0197cef29d6a5614ed821a unfortunately missed that
resume_state_on_host_boot calls down into _hard_reboot always removing
volume secrets rendering that change useless.

This change seeks to address this by using the destroy_secrets kwarg
introduced by I856268b371f7ba712b02189db3c927cd762a4dc3 within the
_hard_reboot method of the libvirt driver to ensure secrets are not
removed during a hard reboot.

This resolves the original issue in bug #1905701 *and* allows admins to
hard reboot a users instance when that instance has encrypted volumes
attached with secrets stored in Barbican. This latter use case being
something we can easily test within tempest unlike the compute reboot in
bug #1905701.

This change is kept small as it should ideally be backported alongside
Ia2007bc63ef09931ea0197cef29d6a5614ed821a to stable/queens. Follow up
changes on master will improve formatting, doc text and introduce
functional tests to further validate this new behaviour of hard reboot
within the libvirt driver.

Closes-Bug: #1905701
Change-Id: I3d1b21ba6eb3f5eb728693197c24b4b315eef821
(cherry picked from commit 26d65fc882e42b824409dff87ff026dee1debe20)
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Do not destroy volume secrets during _hard_reboot

Ia2007bc63ef09931ea0197cef29d6a5614ed821a unfortunately missed that
resume_state_on_host_boot calls down into _hard_reboot always removing
volume secrets rendering that change useless.

This change seeks to address this by using the destroy_secrets kwarg
introduced by I856268b371f7ba712b02189db3c927cd762a4dc3 within the
_hard_reboot method of the libvirt driver to ensure secrets are not
removed during a hard reboot.

This resolves the original issue in bug #1905701 *and* allows admins to
hard reboot a users instance when that instance has encrypted volumes
attached with secrets stored in Barbican. This latter use case being
something we can easily test within tempest unlike the compute reboot in
bug #1905701.

This change is kept small as it should ideally be backported alongside
Ia2007bc63ef09931ea0197cef29d6a5614ed821a to stable/queens. Follow up
changes on master will improve formatting, doc text and introduce
functional tests to further validate this new behaviour of hard reboot
within the libvirt driver.

Closes-Bug: #1905701
Change-Id: I3d1b21ba6eb3f5eb728693197c24b4b315eef821
(cherry picked from commit 26d65fc882e42b824409dff87ff026dee1debe20)

subject: Add shallow_since to parallel git clone
messages: [{'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-07-24 11:23:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-07-24 11:24:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-07-24 11:55:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2021-07-26 14:15:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:\n\nrecheck'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2021-08-12 19:30:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2021-08-14 08:05:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 31542, 'date': '2021-08-17 14:51:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-24 11:23:55.000000000', 'message': "Add shallow_since to parallel git clone

shallow_since controls from which date history repo will be shallowed.
It has prescedence over depth, so when shallow_since is set for the repo
depth won't be used. This is handy
for some repos, like ceph-ansible, that
merge a lot of changes in bunches, which results in bootstrap issues.

Later, shallow_since will be managed with osa CLI and bump will
update this date for the repos in a-r-r.

Change-Id: I8017a01853e8f8950e6e8c7c2337e384af8d7689
"}, {'created': '2021-07-24 11:55:59.000000000', 'message': "Add shallow_since to parallel git clone

shallow_since controls from which date history repo will be shallowed.
It has prescedence over depth, so when shallow_since is set for the repo
depth won't be used. This is handy
for some repos, like ceph-ansible, that
merge a lot of changes in bunches, which results in bootstrap issues.

Later, shallow_since will be managed with osa CLI and bump will

commit_message:
Add shallow_since to parallel git clone

shallow_since controls from which date history repo will be shallowed.
It has prescedence over depth, so when shallow_since is set for the repo
depth won't be used. This is handy
for some repos, like ceph-ansible, that
merge a lot of changes in bunches, which results in bootstrap issues.

Later, shallow_since will be managed with osa CLI and bump will
update this date for the repos in a-r-r.

Change-Id: I8017a01853e8f8950e6e8c7c2337e384af8d7689

commit_message:
Update galera to 10.5.12

Also remove vars/debian-11.yml so that bullseye takes packages from the official mariadb repo
rather than using the distro provided package.

Change-Id: I084f63d071394022b4b2dd6ad1433e4036adc978

Use payloads for ROUTER AFTER_ callbacks

This patch switches over to callback payloads for ROUTER
AFTER_CREATE, AFTER_UPDATE and AFTER_DELETE events.

commit_message:
[EM releases] Move non-voting jobs to the experimental queue

During the CI meeting we agreed that non-voting jobs in the branches
which are in Extened Maintenance (EM) phase should be moved to from
the check to the experimental queue.

This patch is doing exactly that.

Change-Id: Icec5d9be8d78408ad1c758573041225777e86d48

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-08-17 10:02:11.000000000', 'message': "Fix test_fix_argument_yes by closing temp files

The test was randomly failing which could be caused by a race
condition - the temporary files which are created during the
test weren't closed properly which could result in a situation
when they are not yet created but the test is trying to load
them.

Closes-Bug: #1918316
Change-Id: I7a5bf8b1404dbf96955b2eb96fb1a5552760a114
"}]
commit_message:
Fix test_fix_argument_yes by closing temp files

The test was randomly failing which could be caused by a race
condition - the temporary files which are created during the
test weren't closed properly which could result in a situation
when they are not yet created but the test is trying to load
them.

Closes-Bug: #1918316
Change-Id: I7a5bf8b1404dbf96955b2eb96fb1a5552760a114

commit_message:
Don't use plain string SQL statements

Resolve the following RemovedIn20Warning warning:

  Using plain strings to indicate SQL statements without using the
  text() construct is  deprecated and will be removed in version 2.0.
  Ensure plain SQL statements are passed using the text() construct.

Change-Id: I8acdb54d168afa1a7eac270ad6165faa287311ec
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-08-10 15:11:30.000000000', 'message': "setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I540c73978ad858649456d892796bf1e4c2e3e19e
"}]
commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I540c73978ad858649456d892796bf1e4c2e3e19e

commit_message:
Replace use of Table.autoload parameter

Resolve the following RemovedIn20Warning warning:

  The autoload parameter is deprecated and will be removed in version
  2.0.  Please use the autoload_with parameter, passing an engine or
  connection.

Change-Id: Ie039851005c6038591e0e1f6426922ca5b0dcb9a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Replace use of update.whereclause parameter

Resolve the following RemovedIn20Warning:

  The update.whereclause parameter will be removed in SQLAlchemy 2.0.
  Please refer to the Update.where() method.

Change-Id: I50064d16de6e1951b2282fcf9548a0ff2cd0fe55
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

im not sure this can go in unless we are assuming min version of SQLAlchemy across openstack is 1.4 which I dont think is the case right now.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-08-16 11:27:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-08-16 11:28:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> im not sure this can go in unless we are assuming min version of SQLAlchemy across openstack is 1.4 which I dont think is the case right now.

All projects should be using SQLAlchemy 1.4 now, yes [1]. All that's changing here is that this is the new minimum. Given the death of lower-constraints across virtually all projects in the OpenStack ecosystem, that seems a fair assumption.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/40b0fea7ea2e358bad0c26e897761403959aa3d4/upper-constraints.txt#L155"}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2021-08-16 17:46:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Update import of declarative_base()

Resolve the following MovedIn20Warning:

  The ``declarative_base()`` function is now available as
  sqlalchemy.orm.declarative_base()

Change-Id: I5fd707c62d0bfad6e54150c4a3b87aadadbeedb3
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
